ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned many things regarding the cutting edge technology in data centers and novel challenges researchers deal with in computer systems.

A much greater understanding of the context behind big data systems development. 
An understanding of Dr. Khandelwal's system design philosophy.

In this course, I've gained knowledge about some of the most important systems in the "Big Data" domain, and how they evolved through time. Importantly, this information was provided through the original papers of each of these systems, which helped in building a better foundation towards reading and evaluating academic papers. Furthermore, in the course project, I implemented a MapReduce distributed system in Rust with various underlying system designs.
Overall understanding and motivations behind big data systems design.
The course provided extensive knowledge into the development of big data and the systems that support it.

I learned how to quickly and effectively read academic papers, even if the subject is outside my area of study.
I also gained significant experience with the Rust programming language and with the design of a Map-Reduce system.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was very instructive. The projects were also very helpful towards understanding some of the course subjects.

Strengths: 
- Course material is very well designed. A wide variety of topics and approaches. 
- Dr. Khandelwal is a very clear presenter. His depth of knowledge and understanding of the _context_ in which these papers are published is enormously helpful. 

Weaknesses: 
- Most classes consist of: "read a paper at home, write feedback, show up to class, listen to someone talk about a paper you already read, then sit in silence for 20 minutes while other students ask extension questions". 
- In order to write intelligent feedback about the papers, I need to have understood the papers well. And if I've understood the papers that well, the student presentations don't do much for me. 

Unfortunately, I don't have a solution for the problems above. Fostering a "discussion" style environment is a difficult problem. 

Maybe if the student presentations were kept to 10 minutes each, and the discussion for another few minutes -- then it would be useful? Maybe the solution is to watch the student presentations first, _then_ read the paper and respond, _then_ talk about more advanced topics. Maybe we just need more guidance in terms of what cool questions to ask after the paper. IDK.

Strengths: The course covers some of the most important systems in the "Big Data" domain, proving useful insights on which problems each of these systems solve, what its background was at that time and why/why not they became successful. While this domain is enormous, this course offers comprehensive information about its most notable sections/points of interest, in order to provide an excellent starting point for research in this space. Furthermore, I enjoyed the programming project, while it required too much time in order to learn Rust and build a sufficient prototype of the system requested.
Weaknesses: I believe that the students would benefit from one or two classes specific covering Rust, given its rather steep learning curve, as the whole project requires it and it is not required knowledge.
The material of the course and its overall structure was very helpful. The paper review format was very useful for graduate students.
There is a strong emphasis on student discussions in the course which can both be a strong point and a weak point depending on how the students engage with the current material. Overall it was good.

The paper assignments were very instructing and also covered a wide range of datacenter development throughout the past decades.
The assignments were also very useful, as I familiarized myself with Rust and got to choose some design tactics (especially for assignment 2).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but this course has a huge workload.

Yes, I would strongly recommend this class to anyone who would like to gain deeper knowledge about the Big Data domain, its most notable system designs and how they evolved over time, and also to anyone who enjoys in-depth coding assignments.
I would recommend this course to any systems graduate student interested in systems research.
Yes, it's a great course to get an overview of how data centres and distributed architectures work.
